Tripiá¹­aka master Saá¹ƒghadeva of KaÅ›mÄ«ra in the Fu Qin dynastyğŸ”½Human wisdom, samÄdhi, faculties,
Enlightened intentions, path, and corresponding,
Two knowledges, one practice, six small, seven large, seven.
Seven people, eight knowledges, three samÄdhis, three faculties, seven enlightened intentions, eight path-types, corresponding with knowledge, and two knowledge-types, one practice, six, two, seven.
Seven people:
Firm faith, firm Dharma, liberation through faith, seeing attainment, body-witness, liberated through wisdom, both-ways liberated.
Eight knowledges:
Knowledge of dharmas, knowledge of the unknown, knowledge of others' minds, equal knowledge, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of accumulation, knowledge of cessation, knowledge of the path.
Three samÄdhis:
Emptiness, wishlessness, signlessness.
Three faculties:
Faculty of the unknown, faculty of the known, faculty of the absence of knowledge.
Seven enlightened intentions:

Mindfulness enlightenment factor, investigation of phenomena enlightenment factor, energy enlightenment factor, joy enlightenment factor, tranquility enlightenment factor, concentration enlightenment factor, equanimity enlightenment factor.
Eight kinds of path factors:
Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration, associated with knowledge and their kinds:
Forty-four kinds of knowledge, seventy-seven kinds of knowledge, one line, six sevens, seven groups of seven.
Seven kinds of people:
Firm faith, firm Dharma, liberation through faith, seeing attainment, body witness, liberated by wisdom, both-ways liberated.
Eight kinds of knowledge:
Knowledge of dharmas, knowledge of the unknown, knowledge of others' minds, knowledge of equality, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of the end of contamination, knowledge of the path.

How many of these eight knowledges does a person of firm faith accomplish and how many does he not accomplish, up to how many does a both-ways liberated person accomplish and how many does he not accomplish of these eight knowledges?

As for the steadfast faith person, how many of these eight knowledges are accomplished in the past, how many in the future, and how many in the present? And so on up to the liberated person, how many accomplished in the past, how many in the future, and how many in the present?
When the steadfast faith person has the knowledge of dharmas present, how many knowledges are present? And so on up to when the knowledge of the path is present, how many knowledges are present?
And so on up to the liberated person, when the knowledge of dharmas is present, how many knowledges are present?
And so on up to when the knowledge of the path is present, how many knowledges are present?

How many of these three concentrations does the steadfast faith person accomplish and how many does he not accomplish? And so on up to how many does the liberated person accomplish and how many does he not accomplish of these three concentrations?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

As for the person of firm faith, how many of these three samÄdhis are accomplished in the past, how many in the future, and how many in the present? And so on up to the person of complete liberation, how many of these three samÄdhis are accomplished in the past, how many in the future, and how many in the present.
When the person of firm faith has the emptiness samÄdhi present, how many knowledges are present?
When the wishless and signless samÄdhis are present, how many knowledges are present?
And so on up to the person of complete liberation, when the emptiness samÄdhi is present, how many knowledges are present?
When the wishless and signless samÄdhis are present, how many knowledges are present?
When the unknown root of the person of firm faith is present, how many knowledges are present?
The person of firm dharma is also like this.
When the known root of the person of complete liberation is present, how many knowledges are present?
The one who attains by insight and the one who attains by the body are also like this.
When the unknown root of the one liberated by wisdom is present, how many knowledges are present?
Those liberated by both means are also like this.
When the faculty of recollection is present for one of firm faith, how many knowledges are present?
Up to when the faculty of equanimity is present, how many knowledges are present?
Up to when the faculty of recollection is present for one liberated by both means, how many knowledges are present?
Up to when the faculty of equanimity is present, how many knowledges are present?
When right view is present for one of firm faith, how many knowledges are present?
Up to when right concentration is present, how many knowledges are present?
Up to when right view is present for one liberated by both means, how many knowledges are present?
Up to when right concentration is present, how many knowledges are present?ğŸ”½Are dharmas associated with the knowledge of dharmas also associated with the knowledge of the unknown?
If dharmas are associated with the knowledge of the unknown, are they also associated with the knowledge of dharmas?

Are the dharmas associated with dharma knowledge also associated with the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, the knowledge of cessation, the knowledge of the path, emptiness, wishlessness, signlessness, the faculty of knowing the unknown, the faculty of knowing, the faculty of having known, the mindfulness enlightenment factor, the investigation of phenomena enlightenment factor, the energy enlightenment factor, the joy enlightenment factor, the tranquility enlightenment factor, the concentration enlightenment factor, the equanimity enlightenment factor, right view, right thought, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration?
If the dharmas are associated with right concentration, are they also associated with dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½Are the dharmas up to right mindfulness also associated with right concentration?
If the dharmas are associated with right concentration, are they also associated with right mindfulness?
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:
I will explain the forty-four kinds of knowledge:

The knowledge of the suffering of old age and death, the knowledge of the origination of old age and death, the knowledge of the cessation of old age and death, and the knowledge of the path leading to the cessation of old age and death.
Should this knowledge be said to be the knowledge of dharmas, up to the knowledge of the path?
The knowledge of birth, existence, up to formations is also like this.
Moreover, the World-Honored One said:
I will explain the seventy-seven kinds of knowledge:

The knowledge of birth giving rise to old age and death does not take other births giving rise to old age and death as its object.ğŸ”½The knowledge of birth giving rise to old age and death in the distant past does not take other births giving rise to old age and death in the distant past as its object.
The knowledge of birth giving rise to old age and death in the distant future does not take other births giving rise to old age and death in the distant future as its object.

Just as the knowledge of the abiding of the dharma realm is impermanent, conditioned, arisen from causes and conditions, subject to destruction, subject to change, free from desire, subject to cessation, subject to dispersion, and subject to the cutting off of wisdom.
Should this knowledge be said to be knowledge of dharmas, up to knowledge of the path?
Up to the knowledge of ignorance giving rise to volitional formations is also like this.ğŸ”½If one possesses knowledge of dharmas, does one possess knowledge of others' minds?
If one possesses knowledge of others' minds, does one possess knowledge of dharmas?

If one possesses knowledge of dharmas, does one possess knowledge of the minds of others, conventional knowledge, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of the arising of suffering, knowledge of the cessation of suffering, and knowledge of the path?
If one possesses knowledge of the path, does one possess knowledge of dharmas?
Up to when one attains the knowledge of destruction, does one also attain the knowledge of the path?

If one attains the knowledge of the path, does one also attain the knowledge of destruction? [One line is missing.]ğŸ”½If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one also possess future [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses future [dharma knowledge], does one also possess past [dharma knowledge]?

If one possesses past [dharma knowledge], does one also possess present [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses present [dharma knowledge], does one also possess past [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses future [dharma knowledge], does one also possess present [dharma knowledge]?

If one possesses present [dharma knowledge], does one also possess future [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses past [dharma knowledge], does one also possess future and present [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses future and present [dharma knowledge], does one also possess past [dharma knowledge]?

If one possesses future [dharma knowledge], does one also possess past and present [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses past and present [dharma knowledge], does one also possess future [dharma knowledge]?ğŸ”½If one possesses present [dharma knowledge], does one also possess past and future [dharma knowledge]?
If one possesses past and future [dharma knowledge], does one also possess present [dharma knowledge]? [Six sections are missing.]
Up to the knowledge of the path is also like this.

If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one possess past unknown dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½If one possesses past unknown dharma knowledge, does one possess past dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one possess future unknown dharma knowledge?
If one possesses future unknown dharma knowledge, does one possess past dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one possess present unknown dharma knowledge?
If one possesses present unknown dharma knowledge, does one possess past dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one possess past and present unknown dharma knowledge?

If one possesses past and present unknown dharma knowledge, does one possess past dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one possess future and present unknown dharma knowledge?ğŸ”½If one possesses future and present unknown dharma knowledge, does one possess past dharma knowledge?
If one possesses past dharma knowledge, does one possess past, future, and present unknown dharma knowledge?

If one has past and future knowledge of others' minds, does one have past knowledge of dharmas?ğŸ”½If one has past knowledge of dharmas, does one have past, future, and present knowledge of others' minds?
If one has past, future, and present knowledge of others' minds, does one have past knowledge of dharmas?
Up to the knowledge of the path is also like this.
Past knowledge of dharmas and past knowledge of others' minds are one.

Future is two, present is three, past and present is four, future and present is five, past and future is six, past, future, and present knowledge of others' minds is seven. Up to the knowledge of the path is also like this.
I wish to fully explain the meaning of this chapter.
There are seven types of people:
Firm faith, firm Dharma, liberation through faith, seeing attainment, body witness, liberation through wisdom, and both liberated.
There are eight knowledges:
Dharma cognition, subsequent cognition, cognition of others' minds, cognition of the conventional, cognition of suffering, cognition of the origin, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path.
How many of these eight cognitions does a person of firm faith possess, and how many does he not possess?
Answer:
Either one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, or eight.
How is it one?
The answer is:

The cognition of suffering and the cognition of others' minds is one, and the cognition of others' minds is two.ğŸ”½The cognition of the truth of suffering and the cognition of others' minds is three, and the cognition of others' minds is four.
The acceptance of the truth of suffering and the cognition of others' minds is three, and the cognition of others' minds is four.
The cognition of the truth of suffering and the cognition of others' minds is four, and the cognition of others' minds is five.
The acceptance of the truth of the origin and the cognition of others' minds is four, and the cognition of others' minds is five.
The cognition of the truth of the origin and the cognition of others' minds is five, and the cognition of others' minds is six.

The cultivation of the receptivity to the knowledge of the unknown, the cultivation of the knowledge of the unknown, the receptivity to the knowledge of elimination, and the knowledge of elimination, without the knowledge of others' minds, have five; with the knowledge of others' minds, they have six.
The knowledge of elimination, without the knowledge of others' minds, has six; with the knowledge of others' minds, it has seven.

The receptivity to the knowledge of elimination, the knowledge of elimination, the receptivity to the knowledge of the path, and the knowledge of the path, without the knowledge of others' minds, have six; with the knowledge of others' minds, they have seven. The knowledge of the path, without the knowledge of others' minds, has seven; with the knowledge of others' minds, it has eight.
The receptivity to the knowledge of the path, without the knowledge of others' minds, has seven; with the knowledge of others' minds, it has eight.
The same is true for those of firm nature.
How many of these eight knowledges does a person liberated by faith possess, and how many does he not possess?
The answer is:
Either seven or eight.
Without the knowledge of others' minds, seven; with the knowledge of others' minds, eight.
The same is true for one attained to view.

For one of firm faith, how many of these eight knowledges are accomplished in the past, how many in the future, and how many in the present?
Answer:
If one does not know the minds of others, one has one in the past and future, and none in the present.

If one knows the minds of others, one has two in the past and future, and none in the present.ğŸ”½If one does not know the minds of others, one has one in the past, three in the future, and two in the present.
If one knows the minds of others, one has two in the past, four in the future, and two in the present.
If one does not know the minds of others, one has three in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one knows the minds of others, one has four in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one does not know the minds of others, one has three in the past, four in the future, and two in the present.
If one knows the minds of others, one has four in the past, five in the future, and two in the present.
The dharma forbearance of practice, without the knowledge of others' minds, has four in the past and future, and none in the present;
The knowledge of others' minds has five in the past and future, and none in the present.
The dharma knowledge of practice, without the knowledge of others' minds, has four in the past, five in the future, and two in the present;
The knowledge of others' minds has five in the past, six in the future, and two in the present.
The unknown forbearance of practice, without the knowledge of others' minds, has five in the past and future, and none in the present;
The knowledge of others' minds has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
The unknown knowledge of practice, without the knowledge of others' minds, has five in the past and future, and two in the present;
The knowledge of others' minds has six in the past and future, and two in the present.
The dharma forbearance of exhaustion, without the knowledge of others' minds, has five in the past and future, and none in the present;
The knowledge of others' minds has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of the destruction of defilements but not the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past, six in the future, and two in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past, seven in the future, and two in the present.
If one has the receptivity to the knowledge of the destruction of defilements but not the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of the destruction of defilements but not the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and two in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and two in the present.
If one has the receptivity to the knowledge of the path but not the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of the path but not the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past, seven in the future, and two in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past, eight in the future, and two in the present.
If one has not yet attained the cognition of others' minds, one possesses seven in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has attained the cognition of others' minds, one possesses eight in the past and future, and none in the present.
The same applies to one of firm nature.
How many of these eight knowledges does a person liberated by faith possess in the past, future, and present?
The answer is:

If one has not yet attained the cognition of others' minds, one possesses seven in the future, and if they have already ceased without being lost, one possesses them in the past, and if they are presently manifest, one possesses them in the present.

If one has attained the cognition of others' minds, one possesses eight in the future, and if they have already ceased without being lost, one possesses them in the past, and if they are presently manifest, one possesses them in the present.
The same applies to one liberated by insight.

One who is body-witness, one liberated by wisdom, and one doubly liberated all possess them in the future. If they have already ceased without being lost, one possesses them in the past, and if they are presently manifest, one possesses them in the present.Here is the corrected and aligned text:ğŸ”½The Three Times
When the Dharma cognition of a person of firm faith is present, how many cognitions are present?ğŸ”½Answer:
Two.
Dharma cognition and suffering cognition are two, dharma cognition and accumulation cognition are two, dharma cognition and extinction cognition are two, dharma cognition and path cognition are two.
When the cognition of the unknown is present, how many cognitions are present?ğŸ”½Answer:
Two.
The cognition of the unknown and suffering cognition are two, the cognition of the unknown and accumulation cognition are two, the cognition of the unknown and extinction cognition are two.
When suffering cognition is present, how many cognitions are present?ğŸ”½Answer:
Two.
Suffering cognition and dharma cognition are two, suffering cognition and the cognition of the unknown are two.
The same applies to accumulation cognition and extinction cognition.
When path cognition is present, how many cognitions are present?ğŸ”½Answer:
Two.
Path cognition and dharma cognition are two.
The same applies to one of firm nature.
When the dharma cognition of a person liberated by faith is present, how many cognitions are present?
Answer:
Either two or three.

If Dharma cognition and suffering cognition are present, two are present. If Dharma cognition and accumulation cognition are present, two are present. If Dharma cognition and extinction cognition are present, two are present;
If Dharma cognition and path cognition are present, but cognition of others' minds is not present, two are present. If cognition of others' minds is present, three are present.
When cognition of others' minds is present, how many cognitions are present?
The answer is:
Either two or three.

If cognition of others' minds and suffering cognition are present, two are present. If cognition of others' minds and accumulation cognition are present, two are present. If cognition of others' minds and extinction cognition are present, two are present;
If cognition of others' minds and path cognition are present, but cognition of others' minds is not present, two are present. If cognition of others' minds is present, three are present.
When cognition of others' minds is present, how many cognitions are present?
The answer is:
Either two or three.
If cognition of others' minds and path cognition are present, but cognition of others' minds is not present, two are present. If path cognition is present, three are present.
When conventional cognition is present, how many cognitions are present?
The answer is:ğŸ”½Either one or two.
If conventional cognition and cognition of others' minds are not present, one is present. If cognition of others' minds is present, two are present.
When the knowledge of suffering is present, how many knowledges are present?ğŸ”½Answer:
Two.
The knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of dharmas are two, the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of future suffering are two.
The knowledge of arising and the knowledge of cessation are also like this.
When the knowledge of the path is present, how many knowledges are present?
Answer:
Either two or three.
The knowledge of the path and the knowledge of dharmas, without the knowledge of others' minds, are two, if with the knowledge of others' minds, three;
the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of future suffering, without the knowledge of others' minds, are two, if with the knowledge of others' minds, three.
The view of attaining the fruits and the bodily witness are also like this.
When a person liberated by wisdom has the knowledge of dharmas present, how many knowledges are present?
Answer:

Either two or three.ğŸ”½The knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of suffering, without the knowledge of elimination and the knowledge of non-production, are two, if with the knowledge of elimination and the knowledge of non-production, three.

The knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of arising, without the knowledge of elimination and the knowledge of non-production, are two, if with the knowledge of elimination and the knowledge of non-production, three.
If it is the cognition of exhaustion and cognition of non-arising, it is two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion, cognition of non-arising, and cognition of others' minds, it is three.
If it is the cognition of the Dharma and cognition of the path, it is two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion, cognition of non-arising, and cognition of others' minds, it is three.
When the cognition of the unknown is present, how many cognitions are present?
Answer:

Either two or three.ğŸ”½If it is the cognition of the unknown and cognition of suffering, it is two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion, cognition of non-arising, and cognition of the unknown, it is three.
If it is the cognition of the unknown and cognition of the accumulation, it is two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion, cognition of non-arising, and cognition of the unknown, it is three.
If it is the cognition of the unknown and cognition of cessation, it is two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion, cognition of non-arising, and cognition of the unknown, it is three.

If it is the cognition of the unknown and cognition of the path, it is two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion, cognition of non-arising, cognition of the unknown, and cognition of others' minds, it is three.
When the cognition of others' minds is present, how many cognitions are present?
Answer:
Either two or three.
If there is no knowledge of the path, there are two. If there is knowledge of the path, there are three.
When the knowledge of the conventional truth is present, how many knowledges are present?
Answer:
Either one or two.
If there is no knowledge of others' minds, there is one. If there is knowledge of others' minds, there are two.
When the knowledge of suffering is present, how many knowledges are present?
Answer:
Either two or three.ğŸ”½If there is no knowledge of exhaustion or non-arising, there are two. If there is knowledge of exhaustion or non-arising, there are three.
If there is no knowledge of exhaustion or non-arising, there are two. If there is knowledge of exhaustion or non-arising, there are three.
The same applies to the knowledge of the arising and cessation of the truth of suffering.
When the knowledge of the path is present, how many knowledges are present?
Answer:
Either two or three.

The path cognition and dharma cognition, the cognition of non-exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising, and the cognition of others' minds are two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising and the cognition of others' minds, it is three.

The path cognition and the cognition of the unknown, the cognition of non-exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising, and the cognition of others' minds are two. If it is the cognition of exhaustion and the cognition of non-arising and the cognition of others' minds, it is three.
The same is true for one liberated by wisdom.
How many of these three concentrations does a person of firm faith accomplish and how many does he not accomplish?
Answer:
Either two or three.
If the receptivity to the knowledge of the destruction of the contaminants has not yet arisen, he accomplishes two and does not accomplish one.
If the receptivity to the knowledge of the destruction of the contaminants has arisen, he accomplishes all.
The same is true for a person of the dharma.
The liberated by faith, the view-attainer, the body-witness, the liberated by wisdom, and the one liberated in both ways all accomplish [all three].
How many past, future, and present [concentrations] does a person of firm faith accomplish in these three concentrations?
Answer:
If one attains realization by skipping stages based on the emptiness samÄdhi, the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of suffering has no past or future two, but one present one.
The knowledge of the doctrine of suffering has one past emptiness, two future ones added to the emptiness, and one present emptiness.

The perseverance for subsequent knowledge of suffering, the subsequent knowledge of suffering, and the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of origination have one past, two future, and one present one of the wishless.
The knowledge of the doctrine of origination has two past and future ones, and one present one.
The perseverance for subsequent knowledge of origination and the subsequent knowledge of origination.
The past and future are two, and the present is the same as above.
The perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation has two past, three future ones added to the signless, and one present one of the signless.
The knowledge of the doctrine of cessation has three past and future ones, and one present one.

The perseverance for subsequent knowledge of cessation, the subsequent knowledge of cessation, the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of the path, the knowledge of the doctrine of the path, and the perseverance for subsequent knowledge of the path have three past and future ones, and one present one of the wishless.

If one attains realization by skipping stages based on the non-aspiration samÄdhi, there are none in the past, two in the future, and one in the present for the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of suffering.
For the knowledge of the doctrine of suffering, there is one in the past for the non-aspiration, two in the future, and one in the present.

For the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of suffering, the knowledge of the doctrine of suffering, the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of origination, the knowledge of the doctrine of origination, the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation, and the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation, there is one in the past for the non-aspiration, two in the future for the emptiness and non-aspiration, and one in the present for the non-aspiration.
For the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation, there are two in the past for the emptiness and non-aspiration, three in the future, and one in the present for the signless.
For the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation, there are two in the past for the non-aspiration and signless, three in the future, and one in the present for the signless.

For the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation, the knowledge of the doctrine of cessation, the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of the path, the knowledge of the doctrine of the path, and the perseverance for the knowledge of the doctrine of the path, there are three in the past for the non-aspiration and signless, three in the future, and one in the present for the non-aspiration.
The same is true for the steadfast.

Faith-liberated, view-attained, body-witness, liberated by wisdom, and liberated in both ways all possess future [attainments]. If they have already been terminated but not lost, they possess past [attainments]. If they are presently manifest, they possess present [attainments].

Two.
The knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of dharmas are two, the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of future suffering are two.
When the wishless concentration is present, how many knowledges are present?
Answer:
Either two or three.

The knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of dharmas are two, the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of future suffering are two; the knowledge of arising and the knowledge of dharmas are two, the knowledge of arising and the knowledge of future suffering are two;
the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of dharmas, if not the knowledge of others' minds, are two, if the knowledge of others' minds, three;
the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of future suffering, if not the knowledge of others' minds, are two, if the knowledge of others' minds, three.

Two.
